pullRequest.body:
This PR is part of the proof of the Analytic Class Number Formula.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

using the following format:

-->

<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Complex.integral_comp_pi_polarCoord_symm`

`+ abs_fst_of_mem_pi_polarCoord_target`

`+ fderivPiPolarCoordSymm`
`+ fderivPolarCoordSymm`
`+ hasFDerivAt_pi_polarCoord_symm`

`+ lintegral_comp_pi_polarCoord_symm`

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

:v: xroblot can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12892228757/job/35945989116)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12892228757/job/35945988722)

bors d+
Thanks!

```suggestion
theorem lmarginal_const_smul (hf : Measurable f) (r : â„â‰¥0âˆž) :
```

```suggestion
theorem lmarginal_const_smul' (r : â„â‰¥0âˆž) (hr : r â‰  âˆž):
```
I'm not sure this really belongs to this file (it is much more specialized than the generic material already there). What about creating a new file for this?

Ok. So I have created a directory `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.PolarCoord`, move the file `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.PolarCoord.lean` to `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.PolarCoord.Basic` and put the new results in the file `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.PolarCoord.Pi`. 

I also added the proof of the result for `f : (Î¹ â†’ â„ Ã— â„) â†’ â„â‰¥0âˆž` and deduce the complex case from it.

I hope it's better that way. 
Thanks for the review!

I'm surprised you need a measurability assumption for `f` in this theorem. The non-pi version doesn't need it, if I'm not mistaken. Instead of doing an induction like you do (which will definitely need measurability), what about applying directly `lintegral_image_eq_lintegral_abs_det_fderiv_mul` to the change of variables which is the product of the polar coordinates?
Hum, indeed the measurability assumption is troublesome. Let me try to prove things the way you suggested...

Alright, so I was indeed able to prove the result without measurability hypothesis using your suggestion. In fact, I proved the result for Bochner integral too using the same method. And since the proof is much simpler, I could add the results to `polarCoord.lean` without needing extra imports. 

Thanks a lot for the suggestion!

```suggestion
def fderivPolarCoordSymm (p : â„ Ã— â„) : â„ Ã— â„ â†’L[â„] â„ Ã— â„ :=
```
Since it doesn't return a type, it should be lower capitalized. Also, move the argument left of the colon for readability.
Done. I was not sure about the naming of this one. Thanks for the explanation.
ditto

```suggestion
theorem det_pi [Module.Free R M] [Module.Finite R M] (f : Î¹ â†’ M â†’â‚—[R] M) :
```
If you think about what this means (and ignore that you have written it with dot notation), you see why I recommend this order.
Yes, the name made no sense.
ditto
No, `fderivPolarCoordSymm`. When the first letter is not capitalized, immediately following letters that could be capitalized are not either. Yes, the naming conventions are complicated.

Sorry about that. I guess I am still a bit confused about the naming conventions. It is fixed now (hopefully). 

Thanks for the review!

```suggestion
theorem det_fderivPiPolarCoordSymm (p : Î¹ â†’ â„ Ã— â„) :
```
That's the point of the naming convention: when you refer to an object (which has no underscore in its name, by design), then in the lemma name you can put his name unbroken, and use underscores to separate the different objects. In practice, it works very well (much better than the mixed convention we had in Lean 3).

```suggestion
omit [DecidableEq Î¹] in
theorem det_pi [Module.Free R M] [Module.Finite R M] (f : Î¹ â†’ M â†’â‚—[R] M) :
```
Good catch

```suggestion
    (pi (fun i â†¦ (f i).comp (proj i))).det = âˆ i, (f i).det :=
  LinearMap.det_pi _
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Integral/Pi): a version of `polarCoord` for `pi` integrals
